contentrichtext.text: [[File:Campbell County Courthouse at Fairburn, 45 East Broad Street, Fairburn (Fulton County, Georgia).jpg|thumb|left|[[Campbell County Courthouse (Fairburn, Georgia)|Courthouse]] in 1980]] [[Image:Campbell County Georgia.png|thumb|right|Location in Georgia]] [[Image:CampbellCountyGeorgia1895Map.jpg|thumb|right|1895 map]] '''Campbell County, Georgia''' was a [[county (United States)|county]] of the [[U.S. state]] of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] from 1828 to 1931. It was created by the state [[Georgia General Assembly|legislature]] on December 20, 1828 from land taken from [[Fayette County, Georgia|Fayette]], [[Coweta County, Georgia|Coweta]], and [[Carroll County, Georgia|Carroll]] counties, and from the half of [[DeKalb County, Georgia|DeKalb County]] which became [[Fulton County, Georgia|Fulton County]] soon afterward. Georgia's [[Georgia Land Lotteries|Cherokee Land Lottery]] of 1832 also added to the county. The county was named for Duncan G. Campbell, one of the U.S. commissioners responsible for the [[Treaty of Indian Springs]].<ref name=DigitalLibraryOfGeorgia>{{cite web|title=Campbell County|url=http://georgiainfo.galileo.usg.edu/histcountymaps/campbellhistmaps.htm|publisher=Digital Library of Georgia|accessdate=4 February 2012}}</ref> The original county seat was [[Campbellton, Georgia|Campbellton]]; however, when the [[Atlanta & West Point Railroad]] began to plan its route, the town's residents said no due to [[noise (environmental)|noise]] concerns. The [[rail tracks|tracks]] were laid through [[Fairburn, Georgia|Fairburn]] instead, which flourished while Campbellton died out, and Fairburn soon became the new [[county seat]] in 1870. The [[Campbell County Courthouse (Fairburn, Georgia)|Campbell County Courthouse]] was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. The northwestern half of Campbell (and a bit more of Carroll) became [[Douglas County, Georgia|Douglas]] County in 1870, divided on October 17 at the [[Chattahoochee River]]. The remainder of Campbell County was ceded to Fulton County at the end of 1931, along with [[Milton County, Georgia|Milton County]], to save money. The [[legislation]] creating the merger was enacted on August 9, 1929, with Milton being added to the process in 1931. ==References== {{Commons category|Campbell County, Georgia}} {{reflist}} {{Georgia}} {{coord|33.56685|-84.58150|display=title}} [[Category:Former counties of the United States]] [[Category:Douglas County, Georgia]] [[Category:Fulton County, Georgia]] [[Category:Georgia (U.S. state) counties]] [[Category:History of Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:1828 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:Populated places established in 1828]] [[Category:1931 disestablishments in the United States]] {{GeorgiaUS-geo-stub}}
